title: Shift into value stocks could fuel a solid rally, says J.P. Morgan
text:
Bone up on the term “market rotation” if you want to hold your own at the water cooler these days.

Deutsche Bank strategist Jim Reid and his team define that term best as a “big unwind in some popular trades.” In the last couple of days, investors have been intensely pulling money out of momentum stocks — those that have had the best returns over the past year — and into so-called slow-and-steady value stocks. It’s sort of like trading your pet hare for a tortoise.

For examples of the companies that fall into these categories, check out the holdings of iShares MSCI USA Value Factor ETF VLUE, +0.39% and iShares Edge MSCI USA Momentum Factor ETF MTUM, -0.01%.

The Wall Street Journal’s Daily Shot Moving out of momentum

Of course, some analysts say more time is needed time before we can really call these moves a trend.

Diving right into the debate is our call of the day from a team led by J.P. Morgan’s global head of quantitative and derivatives strategy, Marko Kolanovic, who says this value switch may be promising.

“In summary, we believe the value rotation can continue and the broad market could move higher going into October [trade] negotiations, and if real progress is made, continue into a more sustained rally,” they tell clients in a fresh note.

Alas, Kolanovic says the broader S&P 500 may not see much of the glory here, given the index is heavy in companies less ready to pounce on good economic news. It’s full of bond proxies — defensive stocks that could be substituted for low-returning bonds — and companies resistant to short-term trends.

Small-cap, cyclicals, value and emerging markets equities may get much love out of a global upturn, he says.



The market

The Dow DJIA, +0.13%, S&P SPX, +0.11% and Nasdaq COMP, +0.30% are inching higher at the start. Gold GCZ19, -0.10% and the dollar DXY, +0.34% are up, while oil CLV19, +0.59% is climbing ahead of U.S. inventory data due later. Meanwhile, OPEC cut its oil-demand forecast for 2019 and 2020.

Europe stocks SXXP, +0.59% are up on trade hopes and easing expectations for Thursday’s European Central Bank meeting, while Asia markets ADOW, +1.56% finished mostly higher.

Read: ECB needs to push rates further into negative territory without wrecking eurozone banks

The tweet

The Federal Reserve should get our interest rates down to ZERO, or less, and we should then start to refinance our debt. INTEREST COST COULD BE BROUGHT WAY DOWN, while at the same time substantially lengthening the term. We have the great currency, power, and balance sheet..... — Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) September 11, 2019

This morning may have marked the first time President Trump voiced support for negative interest rates, in a mini-tweet storm early Wednesday.

The buzz

Apple AAPL, +1.59% AAPL, +1.59% AAPL, +1.59% unveiled three new iPhones — look away if you hate ugly cameras — and a competitive price tag on its streaming services, putting the spotlight on companies in that space — Netflix NFLX, -0.77%, Disney DIS, -0.43% and Roku ROKU, -1.15%. Apple shares aren’t doing much. Read:Apple’s new strategy: Competing on price.

Amazon AMZN, -0.34% shares are slipping on reports of a U.S. probe into the e-commerce giant’s market power.

Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing 388, +0.33% has made a $36.6 billion bid for the London Stock Exchange LSE, -12.00%, but it’s conditional on the LSE scrapping its takeover of data company Refinitiv, owned by Blackstone BX, +0.68% and Thomson Reuters TRI, -1.99% .

Uber UBER, -0.54% and Lyft LYFT, +1.32% drivers in California are one step closer to becoming official employees, which could be a problem for the ride-share companies.

China has released a list of products to be exempt from the first round of additional tariffs on U.S. goods. Hu Xijin, the widely watched editor in chief of China’s state-controlled Global Times, also tweeted some upbeat trade vibes.

On the data front, producer prices inched up in August, with wholesale inventories coming later.

The chart

Société Générale’s latest market advice lands a spot in our chart of the day. They say pull back on bond exposure and go East for equities.

Société Générale

The quote

Elisabeth Buchwald/MarketWatch EU Commissioner Margrethe Vestager

“Margrethe Vestager will be the most powerful regulator of Big Tech on the planet.” — That was Thomas Vinje, Brussels based antitrust lawyer on Vestager’s expected second term as EU’s competition chief, along with expanded powers as digital czar.

Random reads

Pipes and drums echo through the night air as we gather together to honor our fallen at the @cpdmemorial Annual Candlelight Vigil#NeverForget pic.twitter.com/bgUYbR4b30 — Chicago PD 14th Dist (@ChicagoCAPS14) September 11, 2019

Redditors tell of loved ones lost on Sept. 11, 2001 and near misses that saved others.

Also, today on that anniversary, a rocket exploded at the U.S. Embassy in Kabul.

Eel that can deliver record-breaking jolts discovered in the Amazon basin.

Need to Know starts early and is updated until the opening bell, but sign up here to get it delivered once to your email box. Be sure to check the Need to Know item. The emailed version will be sent out at about 7:30 a.m. Eastern.

Follow MarketWatch on Twitter, Instagram, Facebook.
description: J.P. Morgan quant strategists Marko Kolanovic and Bram Kaplan say this switch to value stocks seen lately could be promising.
